review.title: An Event Calculus Production Rule System for Reasoning in Dynamic and Uncertain Domains
review.abstract: Action languages have emerged as an important field of Knowledge Representation for reasoning about change and causality in dynamic domains. This article presents Cerbere, a production system designed to perform online causal, temporal and epistemic reasoning based on the Event Calculus. The framework implements the declarative semantics of the underlying logic theories in a forward-chaining rule-based reasoning system, coupling the high expressiveness of its formalisms with the efficiency of rule-based systems. To illustrate its applicability, we present both the modeling of benchmark problems in the field, as well as its utilization in the challenging domain of smart spaces. A hybrid framework that combines logic-based with probabilistic reasoning has been developed, that aims to accommodate activity recognition and monitoring tasks in smart spaces.

sections.heading: 3 A Rule-Based Production System for the Event Calculus
sections.text: In this section, we describe Cerbere, a universally accepted rule-based event calculator designed to perform causal, temporal, and epistemic reasoning tasks with information obtained at runtime. Cerbere implements both non-epistemic event calculations and DECKT epistemic expansion. Unlike ordinary rule-based systems used for reactive thinking in dynamic worlds, where the actions leading to the assertion and revocation of facts in a KB have no real semantics and high-level structures, Cerbere uses the high-level structures of DEC and DECKT to define the causal properties of actions and events.

sections.text: A graphical user interface supports the developer in all steps of the design and implementation cycle. Fig. 3 shows Cerbere's visual development environment through a typical interaction loop: The developer designs a domain axiomatization using an intuitive event calculation syntax (Fig. 3a) that divides the system into appropriate Jess rules (Fig. 3b) and finally, at execution time, the programmer is informed about the progress of the argumentation and the establishment of sound knowledge (Fig. 3c). The visual development environment allows the programmer to implement the mental state of rational agents on a more abstract level by modifying only event calculations and optionally specific rules of the Jess program for specialized tasks. New events and observations can be manipulated either manually, by interacting with the user interface, or through a Java interface that enables the system to automatically rationalize the incoming information from an older system before it can manipulate the incorporation or incorporation of incoming tasks.

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Combining Reactive Reasoning with Multiple Models
sections.text: Most reasoning tools for logic programming are capable of generating all valid models that are allowed by their semantics in the face of a particular instance of problem. ASP reasoning tools, for example, produce all the answers that are valid for a particular program. This is typically not the case for rule-based reasoners like Jess or drools, which are primarily used to implement the reactive behavior of a system. In the face of an occurring series of events, the triggering of rules in these systems typically occurs in a deterministic space, and therefore several alternative models are not generated. sections.heading: 4 Reasoning in Situation-aware Dynamic Environments
sections.text: To illustrate the effectiveness and applicability of the proposed system, in this section we describe a hybrid framework for reasoning in intelligent spaces that integrate Cerbere. The application domain of intelligent environments concerns contextual sensor-rich spaces that adapt to and respond to the preferences and needs of users. The envisaged applications materialize a long-awaited application goal for AI, and many of the sub-problems that arise can be addressed by AI methods. An essential step toward issuing common sense behavior and providing meaningful support to the inhabitants of intelligent spaces is the automation of recognition and understanding of the current states of users that involve simple or complex activities. sections.text: Cerbere is a system for conducting online arguments in dynamic domains taking into account causal, temporal and epistemic terms. This article aims to demonstrate its potential for practical domains by outlining its applicability in the context of smart spaces, a field that materializes a long-awaited goal for AI, due to the variety and complexity of the challenges introduced. sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: In this article, we introduced Cerbere, a man of reason who translates the event calculation axiomatization into production rules and manages to support a wide range of characteristics for rational thinking; a description of both theoretical and technical aspects that characterize the rational person was given; in addition, we introduced the integration or Cerbere with a probable component to support follow-up tasks in intelligent spaces; the performance evaluation looked at a domain-independent environment and configurations of a typical intelligent space and revealed the applicability of the system under various conditions; the development of Cerbere will in the future follow the progress made in the underlying formalities to take into account other characteristics; from a technical point of view, we plan to examine parallelization solutions to exploit the progress in multi-core environments so that each instance of Cerbere will be executed in a dedicated core; and it will also be important to evaluate the simplicity of the writing of the rules for sustainability.

On the one hand, so called data-driven approaches adopt primarily a probabilistic and statistical view of information and widely rely on the enormous impact of machine learning techniques in real-world applications (Lu and Fu, 2009; Singla et al., 2010). Their ability to learn from datasets and their capacity to model uncertainty are two of their distinctive characteristics. Knowledge-based approaches, on the other hand, model the rules of inference from first principles, rather than learned from raw data, and typically rely on formal specifications of their syntax and semantics, exploiting symbolic modeling and logic-based reasoning techniques. The expressive power, along with the capacity to verify the correctness properties of their axiomatizations, are key advantages of these methodologies. Data-driven methods are currently the mainstream choice to activity recognition; yet, many activities are characterized by constraints and relationships among context data that can neither be directly acquired from sensors nor can be derived through statistical reasoning alone (Riboni and Bettini, 2011). Even trivial user actions, such as the process of making coffee, pre-assume a significant extent of commonsense and domain knowledge with respect to their causal effects and ramifications. In addition, their compositions, often referred to as situations, have rich structural and temporal aspects, such as duration, frequency and subsumption relations. A seamless integration of data-driven with knowledge-based methodologies is essential for the materialization of smart spaces. Much of current research is working towards this end (e.g., (Riboni and Bettini, 2011; Roy et al., 2011; Helaoui et al., 2012; Skarlatidis et al., 2011). Moreover, activity and situation awareness only pose one step towards the implementation of intelligent environments. Reacting effectively on exceptional situations is equally important, requiring a coherent approach to inference, sensing and actuation, as pointed out by Pecora et al. (2012); still, not many approaches achieve to offer an integrated solution.

metadata.abstractText: Action languages have emerged as an important field of Knowledge Representation for reasoning about change and causality in dynamic domains. This article presents Cerbere, a production system designed to perform online causal, temporal and epistemic reasoning based on the Event Calculus. The framework implements the declarative semantics of the underlying logic theories in a forward-chaining rule-based reasoning system, coupling the high expressiveness of its formalisms with the efficiency of rule-based systems. To illustrate its applicability, we present both the modeling of benchmark problems in the field, as well as its utilization in the challenging domain of smart spaces. A hybrid framework that combines logic-based with probabilistic reasoning has been developed, that aims to accommodate activity recognition and monitoring tasks in smart spaces. Paper under consideration for publication in the Theory and Practice of Logic Programming.
